messages: 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:08): M and I are studying the white-space controls in css3-text
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:19): Topic: text-emphasis
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:19): 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d reviewed Ken Lunde's chart of emphasis shapes
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:19): suggested syntax:
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:20): [ filled | open ] || [ dot | circle | double-circle | triangle | sesame ]
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:21): Suggestion to rename "filled" to "solid"
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:21): But it is confusing with double-circle
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:21): Ishii-san also points out it could be confused with a solid-stroke circle vs. dotted-stroke circle
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:21): Seem to be settling on "filled"
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:21): Filled is the default
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:22): If the shape is left out, then it computes to "dot" in horizontal writing mode and "sesame" in vertical writing mode
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:27): Murakami-san notes that we need text-emphasis-color
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:28): Discussing options for text-emphasis-position
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:28): current values in the spec are before | after
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:28): but does this make sense in Mongolian writing mode, where the before edge doesn't coincide with the "top" edge of the line?
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:29): Ishii-san suggests an 'auto' value, that maps from the language to the correct side
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:29): Japanese uses above in horizontal; Chinese uses below
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:30): We would need a chart in the spec
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:35): probably use "before" for Japanese and traditional chinese, "after" for everything else
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:35): (We have examples of Tibetan text using after.)
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:36): Question: Should text-emphasis marks be applied to punctuation?
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:41): JLTF document says not to apply them to commas, full stops, opening brackets (cl-01) or closing brackets (cl-02)
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:42): should also skip spaces
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:43): If text-emphasis dots conflict with ruby, they should be skipped
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:43): alternatively, the ruby or dots sides can be switched?
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:44): Settled on making the dots go away; it's the author's responsibility to use text-emphasis-position or ruby-position to avoid such conflicts

3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:50): Proposed starting point: follow suggested rules for which punctuation gets emphasized in JLTF document. All punctuation not mentioned in that document gets skipped.
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (07:55): Back to text-emphasis-position
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:00): and the fact that in Mongolian text the before edge is on the left but the top of a line is on the right
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:00): Suggestion:
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:00): text-emphasis-position: above | below
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:01): to avoid confusion with 'before' and 'after' terminology
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:03): Changed to above | below, marked as issue for feedback
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:03): Would need corresponding changes to css3-ruby, though.
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:05): waves to 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6

3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:13): Discussing justification now
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:13): M asks what inter-word is for. It's for e.g. Latin texts, where CJK should not space out
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:14): M and I want more details for auto
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:14): f suggests providing examples; doesn't want to recommend anything because there are many different ways of being smart
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:16): Discuss kashida value.
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:16): It's for Arabic, which has two methods of justification: stretching glyphs, or stretching spaces
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:16): "clustered" should probably shift to 3rd priority
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:16): Everything except those two would be a fallback case
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:22): Discussion of what would be a good default justification algorithm for all scripts
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:22): Probably like distribute, but with "discrete" dropped to 2nd priority
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:27): Ishii-san suggests having that as an example for 'auto' to encourage UAs to do something that works better for non discrete scripts
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:35): Murakami-san draws up the chart for this
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:35): M: This should be the baseline. The UA can do better, but this would be the suggestion in the chart
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (08:36): 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d notes to self that the "connected" and "cursive" categories probably should be last priority for all groups...
